I wish I’d forged ahead after earning my MSW degree in 2011 to get my professional social work license. But the costs and form upon form that had to be completed, even before being allowed to take the national exam, deterred me. I managed my test anxiety well enough to get through grad school, but I let the entire licensing process become a bogeyman to me. 

I’ve worked in my chosen behavioral health field since I graduated, but I’ve had to juggle PT jobs to get an income that was much less than I earned compared to my last FT job before I entered grad school.

A year and a half ago my husband had to go on disability. His long-term disability payments were cut off with almost no notice last fall, nearly thrusting us into poverty. Since the beginning of 2020, we’ve had to withdraw funds from our IRAs, I opened Social Security early, and we—and thousands of others—are struggling to find a FT job for me and PT for him in this pandemic. Not easy at our ages. 

So, yes, REGRET!

In 9th grade I wanted to try out for the basketball team at my junior high.  I had worked on my game, played intramural against the teams players and believed I could compete.  I was standing in line to go up to the gym and two kids I know saw me and said "what are you doing here, you won't make it."  They walked away, I thought for a minute.  Then I slowly walked back to the locker room, changed clothes and went home.    I'll never know.

Never did that again.

In 2006 after a tissue biopsy, I was told I had IBS and didn’t have Crohn’s but I could develop it. I regret not learning more about it & staying up to date so I could make better choices. 

In 2019 after getting very sick, I got diagnosed with IBD. If I had made diet & lifestyle changes a priority, I may have delayed the onset further, if it all. Who knows though? I eat my veg, exercise and am a normal weight. 

On the plus side, after eight months of learning, sorting through fact from fiction, Covid, exercise and a plethora of experts help, the severe inflammation is gone and I’m in remission! 

It wasn’t a great way to lose weight, but now in my forties it’s hard to do, it’s a small plus.

When I was in upper elementary school, my friend and I auditioned for the school pop group. Naively, I think we assumed that both of us would be selected, or neither of us would be. Only 3-4 students were chosen to represent the hundreds on the school roll. I should have been thrilled when my name was announced, but my friend missed out, and, such was her influence and control, I felt compelled to decline. The music teacher contacted my parents and all three spent days imploring me to reconsider. I stubbornly refused. On the night of the performance, I regretted not being up on stage - the group appeared to be having so much fun. But the greater regret, the part that has stayed with me all my life, has been knowing that I didn’t take the chance that came my way because I succumbed to pressure from a person who felt no joy over my achievement; only bitterness as a result of her own disappointment. I’ve always been grateful for the lesson, but the choice I made remains a deep regret.
Listening to someone say I cannot dance and then giving it up.

1) Working too much and not enough time with family and other areas of life improvement. 2) Came from a lower/middleclass family and worked hard to get into a top University. It was hard being surrounded by so many people of wealth (via cars, clothes, dorm accessorizing etc) and got swept away into parties and trying to be popular. My studies were pushed aside which is how I got in in the first place. Thus I regret not reflecting on my choices, not putting education first, and trying to be a people pleaser and subsequently a pushover and manipulated. Now I cannot support my family in the way I want to, yet am working hard to make up for it. However, once you fail in academia, the gates seem to be permanently shut. Education is important and should not be wasted. It should also be ubiquitously accessible.

I was in a PhD program at Florida Atlantic University  (Neuropsy lab). My mentor reduced my time to take comprehensive exams from two days to one. I should have never gone in. I should have switched labs right then. She has seized my dissertation study data and although I had excellent relationships with my professors, they won’t accept me in their lab. I am a 45 year old artist who switched disciplines and I have a 4.0. My Master’s Thesis, my first and only experiment, was published in the Journal of Neuropsychology adult and FAU did a press release on its findings. We were all warned at orientation that if we went above their heads there would be “hell to pay.” That’s why I wouldn’t discuss the accumulation of incidents prior to Comps. Since, gone to Ombuds, Dean Graduate college, Dean of Psy students, Dean of Psy Dept, IRB, Dean of Science. No one wants to touch the evidence. I am the sixth person without a degree in three years. This was a seven year goal. I had one class left.

I regret not leaving a job before they had me wrongfully arrested.  it seems after years of being overlooked for a promotion when I finally made branch manager, jealousy caused someone in the audit department to accuse me of stealing $5,000.  After the arrest and investigation by the police it was discovered that the fraud was done by a client and not me.  If they had just go one more step they would have seen the error.  But that's what it took to propel me into my own business, I never looked backed. Now 11 years later I am in awe of my success by God's grace but with all the signs to leave if I had leave sooner I would have been well ahead of where I am now. So my lesson when you see the signs that it's time to leave whether its a job or someone don't delay because the pain of staying is often times greater than the pain of leaving.
